node.title: 'The world changes next week': Tasmania prepares to open border despite missed vaccination targets
node.description: Tasmania fell short of its 80 per cent vaccination target for those 16 and over last month. Another milestone was missed yesterday. It's charging towards reopening anyway. Here's what you need to know.
node.content:
["Tasmania is charging towards reopening to the rest of the mainland on December 15 \u2014 less than a fortnight away.", "When that date was originally set by the state government back in September, Premier Peter Gutwein was confident the state would reach its vaccine target of having 90 per cent of Tasmanians aged 16 and over being fully vaccinated before it welcomed travellers from interstate once again.", "But vaccination milestones have been missed.\u00a0The state fell short of its 80 per cent target for those 16 and over by Melbourne Cup day last month, and another milestone was missed yesterday\u00a0when the state failed\u00a0to reach the\u00a090 per cent fully vaccinated figure for those aged 16 and up.\u00a0", "And with a non-negotiable deadline rapidly approaching, the state's vaccination uptake for second doses has begun to wane.", "
How far away is 90 per cent?
", "Tasmania has well and truly passed the 90 per cent mark when it comes to first doses for those aged 16 and over in the state.\u00a0Currently that sits at 94 per cent.\u00a0", "When it comes to second doses, however, the state was\u00a0sitting at 87.5 per cent fully vaccinated\u00a0for those aged 16 and over as of 3pm yesterday.", "", "
Katherine Morgan-Wicks says she's \"thrilled\" with how the state's vaccination rollout is\u00a0progressing.(ABC News: Luke Bowden)
", "Although that is less than where the state government and health authorities had hoped we would be, they are still confident the remaining 2.5 per cent will catch up within the next fortnight.", "\"If people continue to come forward for vaccination like they are now \u2026\u00a0we will reach 91 per cent of people aged 16 plus fully vaccinated by the time the borders open on December 15,\" state health secretary Kathrine Morgan-Wicks said yesterday.", "But despite the state missing the milestone, Ms Morgan-Wicks said she was\u00a0\"thrilled\" with how the vaccination rollout was\u00a0progressing.", "\"Particularly noting the distribution of our regional population in Tasmania, we have had clinics across nearly every town centre,\" she said.", "\"To actually reach 94 per cent first dose rate and [have] passed Victoria for example \u2026\u00a0we still have a chance to push that rate even higher.\"", "", "
The state government hoped\u00a0Tasmania would reach the 90 per cent target before it welcomed travellers from interstate once again.(Facebook: Tasmania Police)
", "
What about those aged 12 and over?
", "They might have been added to the rollout later than most,\u00a0but when factoring in the state's 12 and over vaccination rate, Tasmania is currently sitting at 93 per cent first dose, and 86 per cent for second dose.\u00a0", "\"If everybody in the over-12 category \u2026 turns up between now and\u00a0December 15, we will have a full vaccination rate of 91 per cent,\" Mr Gutwein said.", "When looking at figures provided by the federal health department on November 29, isolating the state's 12 to 15 age group sees 72.9 per cent having received their first dose, and 59.9 per cent their second.\u00a0", "Although the second dose figure for those aged 12 to 15 in Tasmania may be lower than expected, that cohort is\u00a0the most recent age group to become eligible for a COVID-19 vaccine in the state.", "That said, Ms Morgan-Wicks is confident vaccination rates for those aged 12 and over can reach the 90\u00a0per cent fully vaccinated milestone \"several days\" after the December 13 target for those 16 and over.", "\"Over the last few days \u2026\u00a0we've actually had an uptick,\" she said.", "\"However, there are 7,000 Tasmanians aged 12 to 15 who are yet to receive a single dose. If you haven't had a first dose, it's not too late.\"", "
What's slowing us down?
", "One of the key takeaways from yesterday's coronavirus briefing was the state government and public health authorities urging people to turn up for their second vaccination appointment.\u00a0", "\"I want to implore people to turn up.\u00a0You've crossed the line and taken the first jab, please get the second jab,\" Mr Gutwein said.", "\"One of the reasons we're not quite at 90 per cent is because of the timing difference between the first and the second dose.", "\"I'm now convinced and very confident that every Tasmanian has had the opportunity to be vaccinated.\u00a0You need to turn up to get that second dose. I will continue to encourage people to do that.\"", "Mr Gutwein also had a particular message Tasmanians aged 18 and over.", "\"From December 6, if you want to go to a pub or a club or to a festival where there is dancing and stand-up drinking, you will need to be fully vaccinated,\" he said.", "\"If you're one of those people that is a couple of weeks' late, some people are even a couple of months late on their second jab, turn up and get it.", "
When can I get my booster shot?
", "Boosters are already being administered in Tasmania for those aged 18 and over who have received their second COVID-19 vaccine more than six months ago.", "To date, about\u00a07,500 eligible Tasmanians have received their booster jab in state-run clinics, and more have been administered in GP clinics and pharmacies around the state.", "Current eligibility rules mean\u00a0those who received their second dose more than six months ago can receive a booster shot.\u00a0So if you received your second dose in June, you will be eligible in January, but if you only received your second jab in November, you will have to wait until June to be eligible.", "This six-month\u00a0interval is currently being reviewed by the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI),\u00a0but Ms Morgan-Wicks said the state would\u00a0be ready to administer boosters if that timeline was adjusted.\u00a0", "", "
Heavily mutated Omicron variant puts scientist on alert
"]
